contentrichtext.text: '''Enford''' is a village and [[Civil parishes in England|civil parish]] in [[Wiltshire]], [[England]]. The parish includes nine small settlements along the banks of the headwaters of the [[River Avon, Hampshire|River Avon]]. Besides Enford, these are Compton, [[Coombe, Enford, Wiltshire|Coombe]], East Chisenbury, Fifield, Littlecott, Longstreet, West Chisenbury and New Town. The [[United Kingdom Census 2001]] recorded a parish population of 577.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://neighbourhood.statistics.gov.uk/dissemination/viewFullDataset.do;jsessionid=ac1f930b30d8251a33137b414aacb8d5d1a9029f24bf?instanceSelection=03070&productId=779&$ph=60_61&datasetInstanceId=3070&startColumn=1&numberOfColumns=4&containerAreaId=790549 |title=Area selected: Kennet (Non-Metropolitan District) |author= |date= |work=Neighbourhood Statistics: Full Dataset View |publisher=Office for National Statistics |accessdate=18 June 2010}}</ref> ==Etymology== The name is derived from the [[Old English]] ''Enedford'' meaning 'duck ford'.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://kepn.nottingham.ac.uk/map/place/Wiltshire/Enford | title=Enford, Wiltshire | publisher=University of Nottingham | work=Key to English Placenames | accessdate=July 29, 2012}}</ref> ==Local government== Enford is a [[civil parish]] in the area of the [[Wiltshire Council]] [[unitary authority]], which is responsible for all significant aspects of [[local government]]. It also has an elected [[Parish councils in England|parish council]], with mostly consultative functions. ==Archaeology== The East Chisenbury [[midden]] is a famous example of a large dump of archaeological material, dating to the 1st millennium BC. Sited on [[Salisbury Plain]], the midden mound contains discrete layers upon layers of flint, charcoal, bones, pottery and excrement. It survives to a height of {{convert|8|ft|m}} and is {{convert|460|ft|m}} wide despite 2,500 years of weathering. The accumulation is believed by some archaeologists to have a ritual basis, with organised deposition of produce and waste being suggested as an explanation for its size and longevity. ==Location== '''Position:''' {{gbmapping|SU139516}} ==See also== *[[List of places in Wiltshire]] *[[List of civil parishes in England]] *[[All Cannings Cross]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Enford}} *[http://www.ourenford.co.uk/ Our Enford] *[http://www.british-history.ac.uk/report.aspx?compid=115488 'Parishes: Enford', A History of the County of Wiltshire: Volume 11: Downton hundred; Elstub and Everleigh hundred (1980), pp. 115-134], retrieved 03:24 Oct 16, 2009 (UTC) *[http://www.wiltshire.gov.uk/community/getcom2.php?id=92 Wiltshire County Council Website page on Enford], retrieved 18:00 Oct 21, 2004 (UTC) {{Wiltshire-geo-stub}} {{coord|51.26339|N|1.80217|W|region:GB_source:enwiki-osgb36(SU139516)|display=title}}<!-- Note: WGS84 lat/long, converted from OSGB36 grid ref --> [[Category:Villages in Wiltshire]]
